 (BALAPPA APPANNA JARAGU)
 XXVIII Additional City Civil and
 Sessions Judge, Mayohall, Bengaluru.

 JUDGMENT

 This suit is instituted by the plaintiffs against the

defendants for the relief of partition and separate

possession of their 1/3rd share in suit schedule

mentioned properties by metes and bounds and to grant

mesne profits and grant such other reliefs.

 2. The case of the plaintiffs' in brief is as

under:-

 That, late Smt. Lingamma, late Smt. Muniyamma

and late Smt. Nanjamma are daughters of late

Munishamappa. Plaintiffs No.1 to 12 are legal heirs of

late Smt. Lingamma. The defendants No.1 to 6 are legal

heirs of late Smt. Muniyamma. The defendants No.7 to

 6 O.S.No.26411/2014

9 are legal heirs of late Smt. Nanjamma.

Munishamappa had acquired suit 'A' schedule

properties. Munishamappa had no male children.

Munishamappa died leaving behind his three daughters

namely Smt. Lingamma, late Smt. Muniyamma and late

Smt. Nanjamma. After death of Munishamappa, all his

three daughters have succeeded to suit properties.

Even though, khata of suit properties were standing in

the names of Smt. Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma,

Smt. Lingamma, was also in joint possession and

enjoyment of suit properties along with his sisters.

There was no partition or division in suit properties

among Smt. Lingamma, Smt. Muniyamma and Smt.

Nanjamma. The defendants No.1 to 9 have no exclusive

right over suit properties. After death of Smt.

Nanjamma and Smt. Muniyamma, defendants No.1 to 4

without knowledge and consent of plaintiffs got

transferred suit properties in their names and

subsequently they have sold portion of suit properties

in the form of sites to 3rd parties. Suit 'B' schedule

properties purchased in the name of defendant No.1 out

of joint family funds selling portion of suit 'A' schedule

 7 O.S.No.26411/2014

properties. The defendant No.10 has acquired suit 'A'

schedule properties for formation of layout. After death

of Smt. Lingamma, defendants have neglected the

plaintiffs and stopped to give any share in crops and

revenue raised out of suit properties. The plaintiffs

have demanded their shares in suit properties. The

defendants making an attempt to get compensation

amount from defendant No.10 by colluding with each

other without knowledge of plaintiffs. On these

pleadings, plaintiffs have prayed to decree suit as

prayed in plaint.

 3. In response to the service of suit summons,

defendants No.1, 3, 4, 7 and 10 have tendered their

appearance before the court through their respective

counsels and contested the case. During pendency of

suit, original defendant No.2 died, by filing necessary

application his LR's are brought on record. The

defendant No.2(a) even after service of the summons,

she has tendered her appearance before the court

through her respective counsel and contested the case.

The defendant No.4 filed his written statement, the

 8 O.S.No.26411/2014

defendant No.1 and 3 adopted the written statement of

defendant No.4. The defendants No. 1, 2(a), 3, 4, 7 and

10 have filed their written statement. Even after service

of the summons, the defendant No.6, 8 and 9 have not

tendered their appearance before the court through

their counsels and contested the suit, consequently

they have placed ex-parte.

 4. The contents of written statement of

defendant No.1, 3 and 4 in brief are as under:-

 The suit filed by plaintiffs is maintainable in law

and on facts and same is liable to be dismissed.

Munishamappa and Smt. Lingamma are unknown to

family of defendants No.1 to 9. The plaintiffs and

defendants No.1 to 9 do not belong to same family.

Defendants No.1 to 9 are claiming lineage from Sri

Venkatappa and Smt. Gopamma. Smt. Nanjamma and

Smt. Muniyamma are daughters of Venkatappa and

Smt. Gopamma. Muniyappa, Chikkapaiah,

Venkataramanappa and Narayanaswamy are children

of Smt. Muniyamma. Narayanappa, Ramanna,

Muniyappa and Smt. Parvathamm are children of Smt.

 9 O.S.No.26411/2014

Nanjamma. It is further specifically contended,

Sy.No.43/1 and Sy.No.43/3, situated at Dasarahalli

Village were purchased by Sonnappa, who is husband

of Smt. Muniyamma. Smt. Muniyamma and Smt.

Nanjamma purchased Sy.No.43/2. Smt. Muniyamma

and Smt. Nanjamma are not related to plaintiffs. Suit

'A' schedule properties acquired by defendant No.10 for

formation of Arkavathi Layout. Suit 'B' schedule

properties acquired by defendant No.1 out of his own

earning. Plaintiffs are not entitled for compensation

amount relating to properties acquired by BDA. Suit 'C'

schedule properties were purchased by Sonnappa in the

auction. Suit 'C' schedule properties exclusively

belonged to Sonnappa. The plaintiffs are not in joint

possession and enjoyment of suit properties. The

plaintiffs have not properly valued subject matter of suit

and they have not paid proper court fees. On these

grounds, defendants have requested to dismiss suit

filed by plaintiff.

 5. The contents of written statement of

defendant No.2(a) and 7 in brief are as under:-

 10 O.S.No.26411/2014

 The suit filed by plaintiffs is maintainable in law

and on facts and same is liable to be dismissed. Suit of

plaintiffs is wholly misconceived, vexatious,

unsustainable and liable to be dismissed. Neither

plaintiffs, defendants No.11 and 12 nor late Smt.

Lingamma and Munishamappa are part of joint family

of Smt. Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma. Genealogical

tree produced by plaintiffs is created for the purpose of

filing suit. late Munishamappa was not Kartha or

original owner of suit 'A' schedule properties. Smt.

Lingamma and Sri Munishamappa are strangers to

family of defendants No.1 to 9. Suit is bad for non-

joinder of necessary parties and bad for mis-joinder of

parties. Title deeds and revenue records indicates that,

suit schedule properties should in exclusive name of

defendants No.1 to 9 for more than 50 years prior to

filing present suit. As such, suit is barred by law of

limitation. Smt. Nanjamma and Smt. Muniyamma are

daughters of Venkatappa and Smt. Gopamma.

Sonnappa is husband of Smt. Muniyamma. Sonnappa

during his lifetime purchased Sy.No.43/1 and

Sy.No.43/3 out of his own income under registered sale

 11 O.S.No.26411/2014

deed. Sy.No.43/2 was acquired by Smt.Nanjamma D/o.

Venkatappa and Smt. Muniyamma under registered

sale deed. Subsequently, there was deed of partition

dated 30.06.1950 and Sy.No.43/2 divided between Smt.

Nanjamma and Smt.Muniyamma. Defendants No.1 to 9

become owners of suit properties. Plaintiffs, defendants

No.11 and 12 do not any share in suit properties.

Present suit filed merely to harass defendants No.1 to 9

and in order to make wrongful gain. The plaintiffs have

not properly valued subject matter of suit and they have

not paid proper court fees. On these grounds,

defendants have requested to dismiss suit filed by

plaintiff.

 6. The contents of written statement of

defendant No.10 in brief are as under:-

 The suit filed by plaintiffs is maintainable in law

and on facts and same is liable to be dismissed. The

plaintiffs have not issued notice to defendant No.10 as

contemplated under 
Section 64
 of BDA Act. The

defendant No.10 -BDA has issued preliminary

notification and final notification in respect of

 12 O.S.No.26411/2014

acquisition of Sy.No.43/1, Sy.No.43/2 and Sy.No.43/3

of Dasarahalli Village for formation of Arkavathi Layout.

Defendant No.10 authority is in possession and

enjoyment of acquired lands. There is no cause of

action for the plaintiffs to file suit against defendant

No.10. On these grounds, defendant has requested to

dismiss suit filed by plaintiff.

 7. On the basis of above pleadings of both parties,

this court has framed the following :-

 ISSUES

 1. Whether the plaintiffs prove that the
 Plaint Schedule Properties are the joint
 properties of the Plaintiffs and the
 Defendants No.1 to 9, 11 and 12?

 2. Whether the plaintiffs prove that they
 are in joint possession of the plaint
 schedule properties along with the
 Defendant No.1 to 9, 11 and 12?

 3. Whether the defendant No.10 proves
 that the suit of the plaintiff is bad for
 not issuing the notice as contemplated
 under 
Section 64
 of the BDA Act?

 4. Whether the plaintiffs are entitled for a
 share in the plaint schedule
 properties? If yes, what is their share?

 13 O.S.No.26411/2014

5. Whether the plaintiffs are entitled for
 mesne profits? If yes, at what rate and
 from what date?

6. Whether the plaintiffs are entitled for
 the reliefs claimed?

7. What order or decree?

 ADDITIONAL ISSUES DATED 03.03.2022

1. Whether the defendant No.7 proves
 that the suit is not properly valued and
 the court fee paid is insufficient?

2. Whether the defendant No.7 proves
 that defendant No.1 to 9 are the
 absolute owners of the Schedule 'A'
 and 'B' Properties?

3. Whether the plaintiffs proves that suit
 'B' schedule property was purchased
 on the income generated from the
 schedule 'A' property by the defendant
 No.1?

 ADDITIONAL ISSUES DATED 15.10.2022

1. Whether defendant No.2A proves that
 the valuation made and the court fee
 paid is insufficient?

2. Whether defendant 2A proves that suit
 is bad for non-joinder and mis-joinder
 of parties?

 14 O.S.No.26411/2014

 3. Whether defendant 2A proves that suit
 is hopelessly barred by limitation ?

 8. To substantiate the case of plaintiffs, the

plaintiff No.4 examined himself as PW1 and produced in

90 documents as Exs.P1 to Ex.P.90. The defendant No.7

examined himself as D.W.1 and produced in 74

documents as Exs.D.1 to D.74.

 9. I have heard the arguments of learned counsel

for plaintiffs and learned counsel for defendant No.4

and I have perused the case records.

 10. My answers to the above issues are as under-

 ISSUE No.1 - In the negative;

 ISSUE No.2 - In the negative;

 ISSUE No.3 - In the affirmative;

 ISSUE No.4 - In the negative;

 ISSUE No.5 - In the negative;

 ISSUE No.6 - In the negative;

 ADDITIONAL ISSUE No.1
 DATED 03.03.2022 - In the negative;

 ADDITIONAL ISSUE No.2
 DATED 03.03.2022 - In the affirmative;

 ADDITIONAL ISSUE No.3
 DATED 03.03.2022 - In the negative;

 15 O.S.No.26411/2014

 ADDITIONAL ISSUE No.1
 DATED 15.10.2022 - In the negative;

 ADDITIONAL ISSUE No.2
 DATED 15.10.2022 - In the negative;

 ADDITIONAL ISSUE No.3
 DATED 15.10.2022 - In the affirmative;

 ISSUE No.6 - As per final order,

 for the following -

 REASONS

 11. ISSUES No.1, 2 AND ADDITIONAL ISSUE

NO.2 :- As these issues are inter-related to each other

and involves common appreciation of facts and evidence

on record, findings on one issue are bearing on other

issue, in order to avoid repetition of facts and for

convenience sake, both issues are taken together for

common discussion.

 12. As per case of plaintiffs, late Smt. Lingamma,

Smt. Late Muniyamma and Smt. Late Nanjamma are

daughters of late Munishamappa. It is specifically

stated in plaint that, late Munishamappa had no male

children. Munishamappa having acquired suit schedule

properties died leaving behind his three daughters who

are Smt. Lingamma, Smt. Late Muniyamma and Smt.

 16 O.S.No.26411/2014

Late Nanjamma to succeeded to his estate. Further it is

definite case of plaintiffs and same is deposed by

plaintiff No.4, who examined as P.W.1 that, plaintiffs

No.1 to 12 are legal heirs of late Smt. Lingamma. The

defendants No.1 to 6 are legal heirs of late Smt.

Muniyamma. The defendants No.7 to 9 are legal heirs of

late Smt. Nanjamma.

 13. It is pertinent to note here that, the contesting

defendants have denied and disputed relationship of

late Smt. Lingamma with that of late Smt. Muniyamma

and late Smt. Nanjamma. It is specifically contended by

contesting defendants, neither plaintiffs nor defendants

No.11 and 12, so also late Smt. Lingamma and

Munishamappa were not part of joint family of Smt.

Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma. It is specific

contention of defendants and same is deposed by

defendant No.7, who examined as D.W.1 that, plaintiffs

and defendants No.1 to 9 are not members of joint

family. It is further contended and deposed by D.W.1

that, plaintiffs are claiming partition through late

Munishamappa and late Smt. Lingamma. These

 17 O.S.No.26411/2014

Munishamappa and Smt. Lingamma are unknown to

the family of defendants No.1 to 9.

 14. According to defendants, Sri Venkatappa and

his wife Smt. Gopamma had two daughters namely Smt.

Najamma and Smt. Muniyamma. Muniyappa, Chikka

Appaiah, Venkataramanappa and Narayanaswamy are

children of Smt Muniyamma. Narayanappa, Ramanna,

Muniyappa and Smt. Parvathamma are children of Smt.

Najamma.

 15. On proper appreciation of pleadings of parties

and evidence of P.W.1 and D.W.1, it is very much clear

that, plaintiffs have claimed late Smt. Lingamma and

late Smt. Muniyamma and late Smt. Nanjamma are

daughters of late Munishamappa. On the other hand,

contesting defendants have denied and disputed

relationship of plaintiffs and late Smt. Lingamma with

that of late Smt. Muniyamma and late Smt. Nanjamma

as well as relationship of plaintiffs and these defendants

No.1 to 9. The defendants have claimed late Smt.

Nanjamma and late Smt. Muniyamma are not

daughters of late Munishamappa. On the other hand,

 18 O.S.No.26411/2014

they are daughters of late Venkatappa and late Smt.

Gopamma.

 16. When there is serious dispute with regard to

relationship of parties, it is heavy burden on plaintiffs to

prove relationship of late Smt. Lingamma with that of

late Smt. Muniyamma and late Smt. Nanjamma as per

Provision under 
Section 50
 of Indian Evidence Act. It is

well settled proposition of law that, when relationship of

one person with another person is in dispute in Civil

suit, same has to be proved as per provisions of 
Sec. 50

of Indian Evidence Act. 
Sec. 50
 of Indian Evidence Act

is an exception to General rule that, hearsay evidence is

inadmissible and opinion based on such evidence. As

per 
Sec.50
 of Evidence Act mere opinion expressed by

conduct of a person, who is a member of a family or

otherwise has special means of knowledge as to

existence of relationship is admissible under this

Section. Such person need not be a member of family.

He may be an outsider. It will suffice, if he has special

means of knowledge. So, a person watching conduct of

members has to be treated as a person with special

means of knowledge.

 19 O.S.No.26411/2014

 17. Further ingredients of 
Sec.50
 of Evidence Act

are as follows:- 1) There must be case, where court has

to form an opinion as to the relationship of one person

to another. 2) In such case, opinion expressed by

conduct as to existence of such relationship is relevant

fact. 3) But a person whose opinion is expressed by

conduct is relevant must be person as member of family

or otherwise has special means of knowledge on

particular subject of relationship.

 18. Herein the case, genealogical tree of family of

plaintiffs and defendants No.1 to 9 has been produced

as per Ex.P.1. In said document, Smt. Lingamma, Smt.

Late Muniyamma and Smt. Late Nanjamma shown as

daughters of late Munishamappa. Admittedly, Ex.P.1

genealogical tree not issued by competent authority. It

is fact that, said document has been prepared based on

information furnished by plaintiff No.4.

 19. It is required to be noted here, just based on

oral contention of plaintiffs and contents of Ex.P.1

genealogy, which is prepared based on information of

plaintiff No.4 it is very hard to come to conclusion the

 20 O.S.No.26411/2014

plaintiffs have proved their relationship with that of

Smt. Late Muniyamma and Smt. Late Nanjamma. 
In

this regard, reference has to be made to decision of

Hon'ble Supreme Court reported in (1983) 3 SCC

118 in case of 
State of Bihar Vs. Radha Krishna

Singh and others
, wherein it is held that, in cases

where the plaint genealogy is the very basis of plaintiffs

case and since there is a tendency on the part of an

interested person or a party in order to grab, establish

or prove an alleged crime to concoct, fabricate or

procure false genealogy to suit their ends, the court

should endeavor to do justice on the materials and

records uninfluenced and undaunted by any extraneous

circumstances. It is further held that, genealogies

admitted or proved to be old and relied on in previous

cases are doubtless relevant and in some cases may

even be conclusive of the facts proved, but there are

several considerations which must be kept in mind viz.:

(a) Source of the genealogy and its dependability. (b)

Admissibility of the genealogy under the 
Evidence Act
.

(c) A proper use in decisions or judgments on which

reliance is placed. (d) Age of genealogies. (e) Litigation

 21 O.S.No.26411/2014

where such genealogies have been accepted or rejected.

On the question of admissibility the following tests must

be adopted: (a) The genealogies of the families

concerned must fall within the four-corners of 
Section

32(5)
 or 
Section 13
 of the Evidence Act. (b) They must

not be hit by the doctrine of post litem motam. (c) The

genealogies or the claims cannot be proved by recitals,

depositions or facts narrated in the judgment which

have been held by a long course of decisions to be

inadmissible. (d) Where genealogy is proved by oral

evidence, the said evidence must clearly show special

means of knowledge disclosing the exact source, time

and the circumstances under which the knowledge is

acquired, and this must be clearly and conclusively

proved.

 20. Herein the case, if principles 
laid down in

above decision are press into service to the facts and

circumstances of case on hand, the contesting

defendants have seriously disputed relationship of

plaintiffs with that of deceased Smt. Late Muniyamma

and Smt. Late Nanjamma as claimed in the plaint and

also as mentioned in Ex.P1, Now it is bounden duty of

 22 O.S.No.26411/2014

plaintiffs to prove their relationship with those persons

by producing sufficient documentary and oral evidence

before the court.

 21. The P.W.1 in his cross-examination has

denied, late Smt. Muniyamma and late Smt. Nanjamma

are daughters of late Venkatappa and late Smt.

Gopamma. It is specific say of P.W.1 that, except

genealogical tree/Ex.P.1, plaintiffs have not produced

other documents to establish relationship of Smt.

Lingamma, Smt. Late Muniyamma and Smt. Late

Nanjamma. Further it is to be noted here, no persons

who being family members of plaintiffs or defendants or

persons having special means of knowledge about

relationship of Smt. Lingamma with that of Smt. Late

Muniyamma and Smt. Late Nanjamma have been

examined before court. The plaintiffs have not taken

any steps to establish relationship of these plaintiffs

No.1 to 12 with that of defendants No.1 to 9 as well as

their relationship with late Smt. Muniyamma and late

Smt. Nanjamma.

 22. As already discussed, P.W.1 has clearly

admitted except Ex.P.1 genealogical tree there is no

 23 O.S.No.26411/2014

other documents or evidence of family members of

plaintiffs and defendants to establish Smt. Lingamma

being daughter of late Munishamappa is sister of Smt.

Late Muniyamma and Smt. Late Nanjamma. Even in

cross-examination of D.W.1, nothing worth elicited to

come to conclusion, Smt. Lingamma is own sisters of

Smt. Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma. Further it is

not elicited from mouth of D.W.1 that, ancestor of

plaintiffs and Smt. Lingamma, ancestors of defendants

No.1 to 9 who are Smt. Muniyamma and Smt.

Nanjamma are daughters of late Munishamappa. The

D.W.1 in his cross-examination has categorically stated,

Smt. Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma are the

daughters of late Venkatappa and Smt. Gopamm.

Absolutely there is no documentary evidence issued by

competent authority to say late Smt. Lingamma being

one of daughter of Munishamappa, she is sister of Smt.

Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma.

 23. According to plaintiffs, Munishamappa during

his lifetime has acquired suit 'A' schedule properties.

Further it is specifically stated by plaintiffs that, suit 'B'

schedule properties purchased in the name of defendant

 24 O.S.No.26411/2014

No.1 out of joint family funds by selling portion of suit

properties. Further it is definite case of plaintiffs that,

defendant No.10 has acquired suit 'A' schedule

properties for formation of residential layout. As such,

plaintiffs being legal heirs of late Smt. Lingamma and

they have got their definite share in suit properties.

 24. It is specifically contended by defendants and

same is deposed by D.W.1 that, Sonnappa, who is

husband of Smt. Muniyamma, during his lifetime, he

acquired land bearing Sy.No.43/1 and 43/3 out of his

own income. These Sy.No.43/1 and 43/3 are absolute

properties of late Sonnapp. In order to substantiate

same, defendants have produced certified copy of sale

deed dated 12.08.1960 as per Ex.D.4.

 25. On perusal of contents of said document,

Sonnappa S/o. Muniyappa had purchased Sy.No.43/1

to an extent of 2 acres 29 guntas and Sy.No.43/3 to an

extent of 29 guntas from Nanjappa and his family

members. The defendants have further produced sale

deeds of vendors of Nanjappa in respect of these

properties as per Exs.D.1 to D.3.

 25 O.S.No.26411/2014

 26. On careful perusal of contents of Ex.D.1, K.V.

Byregowda had sold Sy.No.43/1 and Sy.No.43/3 of

Dasarahalli Vilalge, in favour of Nanjappa under

registered sale deed dated 01.05.1945. Later on

Nanjappa and his family members sold these properties

under Ex.D.2 dated 21.04.1956 in favour of Smt.

Muthamma. Under Ex.D.3, Smt. Muthamma has sold

these properties in favour of Sri Nanjappa and his

family members under registered sale deed dated

07.09.1959. As already discussed, under Ex.D.4,

Sonnappa S/o. Muniyappa had purchased these

Sy.No.43/1 and Sy.No.43/3 of Dasarahalli Vilalge under

JUDGMENT
This suit is instituted by the plaintiffs against the
defendants for the relief of partition and separate
possession of their 1/3rd share in suit schedule
mentioned properties by metes and bounds and to grant
mesne profits and grant such other reliefs.
2. The case of the plaintiffs' in brief is as
under:-
That, late Smt. Lingamma, late Smt. Muniyamma
and late Smt. Nanjamma are daughters of late
Munishamappa. Plaintiffs No.1 to 12 are legal heirs of
late Smt. Lingamma. The defendants No.1 to 6 are legal
heirs of late Smt. Muniyamma. The defendants No.7 to
9 are legal heirs of late Smt. Nanjamma.
Munishamappa had acquired suit 'A' schedule
properties. Munishamappa had no male children.
Munishamappa died leaving behind his three daughters
namely Smt. Lingamma, late Smt. Muniyamma and late
Smt. Nanjamma. After death of Munishamappa, all his
three daughters have succeeded to suit properties.
Even though, khata of suit properties were standing in
the names of Smt. Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma,
Smt. Lingamma, was also in joint possession and
enjoyment of suit properties along with his sisters.
There was no partition or division in suit properties
among Smt. Lingamma, Smt. Muniyamma and Smt.
Nanjamma. The defendants No.1 to 9 have no exclusive
right over suit properties. After death of Smt.
Nanjamma and Smt. Muniyamma, defendants No.1 to 4
without knowledge and consent of plaintiffs got
transferred suit properties in their names and
subsequently they have sold portion of suit properties
in the form of sites to 3rd parties. Suit 'B' schedule
properties purchased in the name of defendant No.1 out
of joint family funds selling portion of suit 'A' schedule
properties. The defendant No.10 has acquired suit 'A'
schedule properties for formation of layout. After death
of Smt. Lingamma, defendants have neglected the
plaintiffs and stopped to give any share in crops and
revenue raised out of suit properties. The plaintiffs
have demanded their shares in suit properties. The
defendants making an attempt to get compensation
amount from defendant No.10 by colluding with each
other without knowledge of plaintiffs. On these
pleadings, plaintiffs have prayed to decree suit as
prayed in plaint.
3. In response to the service of suit summons,
defendants No.1, 3, 4, 7 and 10 have tendered their
appearance before the court through their respective
counsels and contested the case. During pendency of
suit, original defendant No.2 died, by filing necessary
application his LR's are brought on record. The
defendant No.2(a) even after service of the summons,
she has tendered her appearance before the court
through her respective counsel and contested the case.
The defendant No.4 filed his written statement, the
defendant No.1 and 3 adopted the written statement of
defendant No.4. The defendants No. 1, 2(a), 3, 4, 7 and
10 have filed their written statement. Even after service

Provision under 
Section 50
 of Indian Evidence Act. It is
well settled proposition of law that, when relationship of
one person with another person is in dispute in Civil

suit, same has to be proved as per provisions of 
Sec. 50

of Indian Evidence Act. 
Sec. 50
 of Indian Evidence Act
is an exception to General rule that, hearsay evidence is
inadmissible and opinion based on such evidence. As

per 
Sec.50
 of Evidence Act mere opinion expressed by
conduct of a person, who is a member of a family or
otherwise has special means of knowledge as to
existence of relationship is admissible under this
Section. Such person need not be a member of family.
He may be an outsider. It will suffice, if he has special
means of knowledge. So, a person watching conduct of
members has to be treated as a person with special
means of knowledge.

17. Further ingredients of 
Sec.50
 of Evidence Act
are as follows:- 1) There must be case, where court has
to form an opinion as to the relationship of one person
to another. 2) In such case, opinion expressed by
conduct as to existence of such relationship is relevant
fact. 3) But a person whose opinion is expressed by
conduct is relevant must be person as member of family
or otherwise has special means of knowledge on
particular subject of relationship.

(a) Source of the genealogy and its dependability. (b)

Admissibility of the genealogy under the 
Evidence Act
.
(c) A proper use in decisions or judgments on which
reliance is placed. (d) Age of genealogies. (e) Litigation
where such genealogies have been accepted or rejected.
On the question of admissibility the following tests must
be adopted: (a) The genealogies of the families

concerned must fall within the four-corners of 
Section

32(5)
 or 
Section 13
 of the Evidence Act. (b) They must
not be hit by the doctrine of post litem motam. (c) The
genealogies or the claims cannot be proved by recitals,
depositions or facts narrated in the judgment which
have been held by a long course of decisions to be
inadmissible. (d) Where genealogy is proved by oral
evidence, the said evidence must clearly show special
means of knowledge disclosing the exact source, time
and the circumstances under which the knowledge is
acquired, and this must be clearly and conclusively
proved.

Section 7(2)
 and 
Section 35(2)
 of Karnataka
Court Fees and Suits Valuation Acts. When, there is no
contra material placed by defendants and same is not
extracted in cross of P.W.1 that, plaintiffs have not
properly valued subject matter of suit, valuation of suit
properties shown by plaintiffs has to be accepted.
Hence, I answer Additional Issue No.1 dated
03.03.2022 in the negative and Additional Issue
No.1 dated 15.10.2022 in the negative.
48. ADDITIONAL ISSUE NO.2 DATED
15.10.2022 :- The contesting defendants in their
written statement have contended, suit is bad for non-
joinder of necessary parties. While cross-examining
P.W.1 an attempt was made to suggest, daughter of
Smt. Nanjamma by name Smt. Parvathamma not made
as party to suit.
49. It is worth to note here that, in suit for
partition all family members are not necessary parties.
If any person who is head of particular branch is made
as party to suit, that is sufficient, he represents all
members of that branch.
50. Further it is to be noted here, while cross-
examining P.W.1 it is suggested, there is no person by
name Muniraju. It is well settled proposition of law
that, suit cannot be dismissed for mis-joinder of parties.
Hence, I answer Additional Issue No.2 dated
15.10.2022 in the negative.
51.ADDITIONAL ISSUE NO.3 DATED
15.10.2022 :- It is specific contention of defendants
that, suit of the plaintiffs is hopelessly barred by law of
limitation. It is pertinent to note here that, it is not
mentioned by plaintiffs when father of Smt. Lingamma
by name Munishamappa died. No death certificate of
Munishamappa has been produced before the court. If
entire case of plaintiffs is accepted all properties
belonged to Munishamappa, immediately after death of
Munishamappa, cause of action accrues to Smt.
Lingamma or plaintiffs to claim share in suit properties.
Herein the case, absolutely there is no material to show,
suit properties owned and possessed by
Munishamappa.
52. It is evident from revenue records itself, since
1969 itself name of Sonnappa, thereafter names
Muniyappa, Chikkapaiah, Vekaramanappa, and
Narayanaswamy and names of Smt. Muniyamma and
Smt. Nanjamma have been continued in revenue
records pertaining to suit properties. Suit filed in the
year 2014.
53. Even assuming for movement, plaintiffs or late
Smt. Lingamma have got any right or interest over suit
properties, they would have challenged those revenue
records within reasonable time. As such, suit is
hopelessly barred by law of limitation. Hence I answer
Additional Issue No.3 dated 15.10.2022 in the
affirmative.
54. ISSUES NO.4 TO 6 :- As these issues are
inter-related to each other and involves common
appreciation of facts and evidence on record, findings on
one issue are bearing on other issue, in order to avoid
repetition of facts and for convenience sake, both issues
are taken together for common discussion.
55. As already discussed, plaintiffs have failed to
establish their relationship with defendants and
relationship of late Smt. Lingamma with that of Smt.
Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma as claimed in plaint.
Further more, plaintiffs have failed to establish suit
schedule properties were originally acquired by
Munishamappa, who is father of late Smt. Lingamma.
The plaintiffs have failed to establish, they being joint
owners of suit properties, they are in joint possession
and enjoyment of suit properties along with defendants
No.1 to 9, 11 and 12. Further more, suit 'A' schedule
properties already acquired by BDA for formation of
Arkavathi Layout. When, plaintiffs are not entitled for
any share in suit properties, question of mesne profits
as prayed by plaintiffs does not arise.
56. Further it is to be noted here, the plaintiffs
themselves have pleaded, defendants have sold portion
of schedule properties in the forms of sites to 3 rd parties.
The defendants have specifically contended, Smt.
Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma have entered into
partition in respect of Sy.No.43/2 of Dasarhalli Village,
In this regard, there is no effective cross examination of
57. The D.W.1 has specifically stated, in the year
1950 Smt. Muniyamma and Smt. Nanjamma have
effected partition. The learned counsel for defendants
has rightly relied upon decision reported in (2016) 12

SCC 288 in case of 
Muddasani Venkata Narasiah

(dead) by LRs Vs. Muddasani Sarojana
, wherein it is
held that, cross-examination is a matter of substance
not of procedure one is required to put one's own
version in cross-examination of opponent. The effect of
non cross-examination is that, statement of witnesses
has not been disputed.
58. It is to be noted here, though plaintiffs have
pleaded, defendants have sold portion of suit properties
in the form of sites but they have not sought for any
declaration with regard those sale deeds. On this count
also, suit of plaintiffs is not maintainable. In this
regard, learned counsel for defendants has relied upon
decision of Hon'ble High Court in MFA
NO.100407/2021 in case of Sri Omkar S/o.
Sambhaji Yadav and Others S. Sambhaji S/o.
Madhu Yadav, wherein it is held that, it is settled
proposition that, even if plaintiffs contents that,
registered sale deed executed by defendant No.1 in
favour of defendant No.2 not for family necessity and
they are bound to ignore said sale deed, they have to
seek a declaration to that effect. Off course, plaintiffs
are not signatories to sale deed in question are not
required to seek a decree for setting aside sale deed.
But, seeking declaration in respect of sale deed is very
much necessary. Admittedly, there is no prayer by
plaintiffs in respect of sale deeds executed by
defendants of sites in suit properties. Suit filed by
plaintiffs is devoid of merits and liable to be dismissed.
Hence, I answer issues No.4 to 6 in the negative.
59. ISSUES No.7 :- In view of the above said
findings on Issue Nos. 1 to 6 and additional issues, I
proceed to pass the following:-
ORDER
The suit of the plaintiffs is hereby
dismissed with costs.
Draw decree accordingly.
